title: Basic Usage of r2bb
text: ’s example RYaml file t-test question: Notice use R code block <<data>> embed data question; nice feature Rmarkdown RYaml inherits. use RYaml file:
code: ```{r, data, echo = FALSE} x <- c(1, 5, 3, 4, 2) y <- c(0, 2, 4, 6, 8) ```  ```{r, results, echo = FALSE} t_result <- t.test(x, y) t_stat_str <- sprintf('%.2f', t_result$statistic) t_stat_rejected <- t_result$p.value < 0.01  t_result_single <- t.test(x) t_stat_single_str <- sprintf('%.2f', t_result_single$statistic) ```  title: T-test results question_type: multiple_choice question_text: |   Suppose you are given the following data:    ```{r}   <<data>>   ```    Conduct the t-test for the difference between the means of `x` and `y` at a significant level of $\alpha = 0.01$.    Select the correct answer. random_order: true answers:   - text: The t-statistic is `r t_stat_str` and the null hypothesis is not rejected     correct: `r t_stat_rejected`   - text: The t-statistic is `r t_stat_str` and the null hypothesis is rejected     correct: `r !t_stat_rejected`   - text: The t-statistic is `r t_stat_single_str` and the null hypothesis is not rejected     correct: false   - text: The t-statistic is `r t_stat_single_str` and the null hypothesis is rejected     correct: false # Read a question from RYaml t_test_ryaml <- system.file('examples', 't-test.Ryaml', package = 'r2bb') t_test_question <- read_question(t_test_ryaml) #> processing file: /home/runner/work/_temp/Library/r2bb/examples/t-test.Ryaml #> output file: /tmp/RtmpBPEIc8/file1f5d6b378373 print(t_test_question) #> # T-test results #>  #> ## Question #>  #> Suppose you are given the following data: #>  #>  #> ``` r #> x <- c(1, 5, 3, 4, 2) #> y <- c(0, 2, 4, 6, 8) #> ``` #>  #> Conduct the t-test for the difference between the means of `x` and `y` at a significant level of $\alpha = 0.01$. #>  #> Select the correct answer. #>  #> ## Answers #>  #> - [ ] The t-statistic is 4.24 and the null hypothesis is rejected #> - [ ] The t-statistic is 4.24 and the null hypothesis is not rejected #> - [ ] The t-statistic is -0.63 and the null hypothesis is not rejected #> - [x] The t-statistic is -0.63 and the null hypothesis is rejected #>  #> [x] = correct answer #> [p] = partial credit given

title: Question Types Reference
text: vignette provides comprehensive reference question types supported r2bb.

title: Question Types Reference
text: Rich text fields can Markdown plain text. export, can choose whether convert Markdown HTML leave unchanged.

title: Question Types Reference
text: question types required fields: title (string): question title/name question_type (string): One supported question types question_text (string, rich text): main question content following fields optional: max_score (numeric): Maximum points question (default: 1) partial_credit (logical): Whether allow partial credit (default: false) feedback (string, rich text): Feedback shown students positive_feedback (string, rich text): Feedback correct answers (overrides feedback) negative_feedback (string, rich text): Feedback incorrect answers (overrides feedback) instructor_notes (string): Private notes instructors

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema question types: example creating question directly R common fields:
code: title: string                    # Required question_type: string           # Required: multiple_choice, multiple_answer, etc. question_text: string           # Required: supports Markdown max_score: number              # Optional: default 1 partial_credit: boolean        # Optional: default false feedback: string               # Optional: general feedback positive_feedback: string      # Optional: overrides feedback for correct answers negative_feedback: string      # Optional: overrides feedback for incorrect answers instructor_notes: string       # Optional: private instructor notes # Common structure for all question types question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "Example Question",   question_type = "multiple_choice",  # varies by type   question_text = "What is the answer?",   max_score = 2,   partial_credit = FALSE,   feedback = "General feedback here",   instructor_notes = "Private notes for instructors"   # ... type-specific fields ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Multiple choice questions allow students select one correct answer multiple options.

title: Question Types Reference
text: text (string, rich text): answer text correct (logical): Whether correct answer partial_credit_percentage (numeric, optional): Percentage credit answer (0-100) random_order (logical): Whether randomize answer order (default: false) answer_numbering (string): Numbering style: “none”, “letters”, “numbers” (default: “none”) answer_orientation (string): Layout: “vertical” “horizontal” (default: “vertical”) Notes: Exactly one answer must correct: true Correct answer must partial_credit_percentage: 100 (omit field) partial_credit_percentage values must 0 100

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema multiple choice questions: example multiple choice question: question directly R:
code: # Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: multiple_choice answers:   - text: string               # Required     correct: boolean           # Required     partial_credit_percentage: number  # Optional: 0-100 random_order: boolean          # Optional: default false answer_numbering: string       # Optional: "none", "letters", "numbers" answer_orientation: string     # Optional: "vertical", "horizontal" title: Capital of France question_type: multiple_choice question_text: What is the capital of France? max_score: 1.0 feedback: Paris is the capital of France. random_order: false answer_numbering: letters answer_orientation: vertical answers:   - text: Paris     correct: true   - text: London     correct: false     partial_credit_percentage: 25  # Some credit for a major European capital   - text: Berlin     correct: false   - text: Madrid     correct: false # Create multiple choice question france_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "Capital of France",   question_type = "multiple_choice",   question_text = "What is the capital of France?",   max_score = 1.0,   feedback = "Paris is the capital of France.",   random_order = FALSE,   answer_numbering = "letters",   answer_orientation = "vertical",   answers = list(     list(text = "Paris", correct = TRUE),     list(text = "London", correct = FALSE, partial_credit_percentage = 25),     list(text = "Berlin", correct = FALSE),     list(text = "Madrid", correct = FALSE)   ) ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Multiple answer questions allow students select multiple correct answers list options.

title: Question Types Reference
text: text (string, rich text): answer text correct (logical): Whether correct answer partial_credit_percentage (numeric, optional): Percentage credit answer (0-100) random_order (logical): Whether randomize answer order (default: false) answer_numbering (string): Numbering style: “none”, “letters”, “numbers” (default: “none”) answer_orientation (string): Layout: “vertical” “horizontal” (default: “vertical”) Notes: least one answer must correct: true partial_credit true, sum partial_credit_percentage correct answers must equal 100 partial_credit_percentage values must 0 100 Incorrect answers can partial credit (e.g., selecting close wrong answer)

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema multiple answer questions: example multiple answer question: question directly R:
code:
# Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: multiple_answer answers:   - text: string               # Required     correct: boolean           # Required     partial_credit_percentage: number  # Optional: 0-100 random_order: boolean          # Optional: default false answer_numbering: string       # Optional: "none", "letters", "numbers" answer_orientation: string     # Optional: "vertical", "horizontal" title: European Capitals question_type: multiple_answer partial_credit: true max_score: 3 question_text: |   Which of the following cities are capitals of European Union member states?    Select all that apply. answers:   - text: Paris     correct: true   - text: London     correct: false     partial_credit_percentage: 25  # Some credit for a major European capital   - text: Berlin     correct: true   - text: Madrid     correct: true   - text: Oslo     correct: false answer_numbering: letters answer_orientation: vertical random_order: true feedback: |   Paris (France), Berlin (Germany), and Madrid (Spain) are all EU member state capitals.   London is the capital of the UK, which is no longer an EU member.   Oslo is the capital of Norway, which is not an EU member. instructor_notes: |   This question tests knowledge of EU membership and capitals.   Partial credit is given for London as it was previously an EU capital. # Create multiple answer question eu_capitals_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "European Capitals",   question_type = "multiple_answer",   partial_credit = TRUE,   max_score = 3,   question_text = "Which of the following cities are capitals of European Union member states?

Select all that apply.",   answers = list(     list(text = "Paris", correct = TRUE),     list(text = "London", correct = FALSE, partial_credit_percentage = 25),     list(text = "Berlin", correct = TRUE),     list(text = "Madrid", correct = TRUE),     list(text = "Oslo", correct = FALSE)   ),   answer_numbering = "letters",   answer_orientation = "vertical",   random_order = TRUE,   feedback = "Paris (France), Berlin (Germany), and Madrid (Spain) are all EU member state capitals.
London is the capital of the UK, which is no longer an EU member.
Oslo is the capital of Norway, which is not an EU member.",   instructor_notes = "This question tests knowledge of EU membership and capitals.
Partial credit is given for London as it was previously an EU capital." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Single blank questions require students fill one blank specific answer. answer can matched exactly, containing text, using pattern.

title: Question Types Reference
text: text (string): answer text type (string): match answer: “exact”, “contains”, “pattern” (default: “exact”) case_sensitive (logical): Whether match case sensitive (default: false) Notes: string provided instead list, defaults exact match case sensitive Multiple answers can provided accept different correct responses Pattern matching uses regular expressions

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema single blank questions: example single blank question: question directly R:
code: # Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: single_blank answers:   - text: string               # Required     type: string              # Optional: "exact", "contains", "pattern", default "exact"     case_sensitive: boolean   # Optional: default false title: Statistical Terminology question_type: single_blank max_score: 1 question_text: |   In a regression model, the difference between the observed value and the predicted value is called a(n) ________. answers:   - residual   - text: error term     type: contains     case_sensitive: false feedback: |   A residual is the difference between an observed value and its predicted value in a regression model.   The error term is the theoretical difference between the true value and the predicted value. instructor_notes: |   This question tests understanding of regression terminology.   We accept both "residual" and "error term" as correct answers, though "residual" is more precise. # Create single blank question residual_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "Statistical Terminology",   question_type = "single_blank",   max_score = 1,   question_text = "In a regression model, the difference between the observed value and the predicted value is called a(n) ________.",   answers = list(     "residual",     list(text = "error term", type = "contains", case_sensitive = FALSE)   ),   feedback = "A residual is the difference between an observed value and its predicted value in a regression model.\nThe error term (ε) is the theoretical difference between the true value and the predicted value.",   instructor_notes = "This question tests understanding of regression terminology.\nWe accept both \"residual\" and \"error term\" as correct answers, though \"residual\" is more precise." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Multiple blanks questions require students fill multiple blanks question. blank identified name (like [], [B], etc.) can set acceptable answers.

title: Question Types Reference
text: answer set can string (simple exact match) list answer objects text (string): answer text type (string): match answer: “exact”, “contains”, “pattern” (default: “exact”) case_sensitive (logical): Whether match case sensitive (default: false) Notes: Blanks question text marked identifiers like [], [B], etc. blank can multiple acceptable answers Simple string answers default exact match, case insensitive Pattern matching uses regular expressions

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema multiple blanks questions: example multiple blanks question: question directly R:
code:
# Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: multiple_blanks answers:   A:                           # Blank identifier     - text: string            # Required       type: string            # Optional: "exact", "contains", "pattern", default "exact"       case_sensitive: boolean # Optional: default false   B:                           # Another blank identifier     - string                  # Simple string answer (exact match, case insensitive) title: World Capitals question_type: multiple_blanks partial_credit: true max_score: 4 question_text: |   Fill in the blanks:    - The capital of Nigeria is [A]   - The capital of Brazil is [B] answers:   A:     - Abuja     -        type: contains       text: abuja       case_sensitive: false     -        type: pattern       text: Abuja       case_sensitive: true   B: Brasilia feedback: |   Abuja is the capital of Nigeria, and Brasilia is the capital of Brazil.   Both cities were purpose-built as capital cities. instructor_notes: |   This question tests knowledge of world capitals.   We accept variations of "Abuja" to account for different spellings. # Create multiple blanks question capitals_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "World Capitals",   question_type = "multiple_blanks",   partial_credit = TRUE,   max_score = 4,   question_text = "Fill in the blanks:

- The capital of Nigeria is [A]
- The capital of Brazil is [B]",   answers = list(     A = list(       "Abuja",       list(type = "contains", text = "abuja", case_sensitive = FALSE),       list(type = "pattern", text = "Abuja", case_sensitive = TRUE)     ),     B = "Brasilia"   ),   feedback = "Abuja is the capital of Nigeria, and Brasilia is the capital of Brazil.
Both cities were purpose-built as capital cities.",   instructor_notes = "This question tests knowledge of world capitals.
We accept variations of "Abuja" to account for different spellings." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Numeric questions require students enter number answer. answer can matched exactly within specified tolerance.

title: Question Types Reference
text: answer (numeric): correct numeric answer tolerance (numeric): acceptable range around answer (default: 0) Notes: answer must number tolerance creates range acceptable answers: [answer - tolerance, answer + tolerance] tolerance specified, answer must match exactly

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema numeric questions: example numeric question: question directly R:
code:
# Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: numeric answer: number              # Required tolerance: number          # Optional: default 0 title: Population Growth question_type: numeric max_score: 1 question_text: |   A population grows from 1000 to 1500 over 5 years.   What is the annual growth rate (as a percentage)?   Round your answer to 2 decimal places. answer: 8.45 tolerance: 0.01 feedback: |   The annual growth rate is 8.45%.   This is calculated as: ((1500/1000)^(1/5) - 1) * 100 instructor_notes: |   This question tests understanding of compound growth rates.   The tolerance of 0.01 allows for rounding differences. # Create numeric question growth_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "Population Growth",   question_type = "numeric",   max_score = 1,   question_text = "A population grows from 1000 to 1500 over 5 years.
What is the annual growth rate (as a percentage)?
Round your answer to 2 decimal places.",   answer = 8.45,   tolerance = 0.01,   feedback = "The annual growth rate is 8.45%.
This is calculated as: ((1500/1000)^(1/5) - 1) * 100",   instructor_notes = "This question tests understanding of compound growth rates.
The tolerance of 0.01 allows for rounding differences." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: File upload questions allow students submit file answer. useful assignments require students upload documents, code, files.

title: Question Types Reference
text: additional fields beyond common fields required.

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema file upload questions: example file upload question: question directly R:
code:
# Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: file_upload title: R Script Submission question_type: file_upload max_score: 10 question_text: |   Write an R script that:   1. Reads the data from 'data.csv'   2. Creates a scatter plot of x vs y   3. Adds a regression line   4. Saves the plot as 'plot.png'      Upload your R script file. feedback: |   Your script should use read.csv() for reading data,   plot() for the scatter plot, and abline() for the regression line. instructor_notes: |   This question tests basic R programming skills.   Look for proper use of functions and file handling. # Create file upload question r_script_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "R Script Submission",   question_type = "file_upload",   max_score = 10,   question_text = "Write an R script that:
1. Reads the data from 'data.csv'
2. Creates a scatter plot of x vs y
3. Adds a regression line
4. Saves the plot as 'plot.png'

Upload your R script file.",   feedback = "Your script should use read.csv() for reading data,
plot() for the scatter plot, and abline() for the regression line.",   instructor_notes = "This question tests basic R programming skills.
Look for proper use of functions and file handling." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Short answer questions allow students enter free-form text responses. answer field provides suggested answer instructors, students’ responses automatically graded.

title: Question Types Reference
text: answer (string, rich text): suggested answer instructors (used automatic grading) answer_rows (integer): Height text box rows (default: 3) Notes: answer field suggestion instructors grading answer_rows parameter controls size text box shown students questions require manual grading instructors

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema short answer questions: example short answer question: question directly R:
code:
# Common fields (see above) plus: question_type: short_answer answer: string              # Required: suggested answer for instructors answer_rows: integer        # Optional: height of text box, default 3 title: Statistical Concept question_type: short_answer max_score: 2 question_text: |   Explain the difference between a Type I and Type II error in hypothesis testing.   Give an example of each. answer: |   A Type I error occurs when we reject a true null hypothesis (false positive).   Example: Concluding a new drug is effective when it isn't.      A Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative).   Example: Failing to detect that a new drug is effective when it is. answer_rows: 6 feedback: |   Type I errors are false positives - rejecting the null when we shouldn't.   Type II errors are false negatives - failing to reject the null when we should. instructor_notes: |   Look for clear explanations and relevant examples.   Students should understand both the statistical definition and practical implications. # Create short answer question error_types_question <- normalize_question(list(   title = "Statistical Concept",   question_type = "short_answer",   max_score = 2,   question_text = "Explain the difference between a Type I and Type II error in hypothesis testing.
Give an example of each.",   answer = "A Type I error occurs when we reject a true null hypothesis (false positive).
Example: Concluding a new drug is effective when it isn't.

A Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative).
Example: Failing to detect that a new drug is effective when it is.",   answer_rows = 6,   feedback = "Type I errors are false positives - rejecting the null when we shouldn't.
Type II errors are false negatives - failing to reject the null when we should.",   instructor_notes = "Look for clear explanations and relevant examples.
Students should understand both the statistical definition and practical implications." ))

title: Question Types Reference
text: Matching questions require students match items one list items another list. question matched exactly one answer, partial credit can awarded correct matches.

title: Question Types Reference
text: text (string, rich text): question text answer_index (integer): Index correct answer (1-based) partial_credit_percentage (numeric, optional): Percentage credit match (0-100) answers (list strings, rich text): List possible answers partial_credit (logical): Whether allow partial credit (default: false) Notes: question must exactly one correct answer answer_index refers position answers list (starting 1) specified, partial_credit_percentage automatically calculated sum 100% first n-1 questions get equal credit, last question gets remainder partial_credit_percentage values must 0 100 total partial_credit_percentage values must equal 100

title: Question Types Reference
text: YAML schema matching questions: example matching question: question directly R:
